Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: Virtualizing Coordinated Resource Management of Flows on Handhelds with VIADUCT

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Handheld devices such as cell phones, tablets and wearables, are gaining
rapid adoption in a ubiquitous world. Correspondingly, there is an
explosion of very demanding and interactive applications such as media
streaming, interactive games, video conferencing and social networking,
that users are deploying on such devices. Despite tremendous
improvements in the energy efficiencies of individual components found
in these devices, piece-meal optimizations of hardware components are
inadequate to accommodate the demanding needs of these applications that
employ multiple CPU cores, accelerators, memory systems, system
peripherals and sensors, concurrently in very sophisticated ways. Lack
of coordination among system resources leads to low resource utilization
and poor system-level energy efficiencies when running such
applications. Rather than throw more hardware at this problem, this
project proposes VIADUCT, which allocates and orchestrates system-level
resources to boost parallelism and resource utilization for these
platforms in a more energy-efficient fashion.

Recognizing that many of these applications periodically process frames
of data that need to flow in a pipelined manner through several hardware
components within soft real-time bounds, VIADUCT creates a virtual
channel per flow of such frames in an application. The channel holds
resources allocated across all the hardware components, with runtime
coordination to ensure seamless frame movements without the conventional
interface inefficiencies across the components. Fine-grain scheduling
and resource management leverages knowledge of high level semantics to
provide Quality-of-Service (QoS) for each flow in the most
energy-efficient fashion. The specific research contributions are in
hardware interfaces, mechanisms and policies to chain the hardware
components for creating a virtual channel for a flow, architecting the
memory system as an efficient conduit to sustain this flow, and
designing the system to sustain several concurrent flows. The project
aims to provide a holistic evaluation testbed for such platforms amongst
the broader research community, and also aims to involve
under-represented groups in the research and enhance Penn State?s
curriculum in related topics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this VIADUCT project is to investigate the reasons of energy inefficiencies of numerous hardware components (e.g., CPU cores, accelerators/IPs, DRAM, peripherals and sensors) in handheld/mobile SoCs, and to create a new architecture for handhelds which allocates and coordinates the hardware resources for a flow, to enhance parallelism and boost utilization, yielding high throughput concurrent flows on the platform. The rationale for simultaneously optimizing multiple hardware as in a flow is that many applications such as video streaming, interactive games, social networking, VR/AR, etc., process frames of data periodically and stress several hardware components concurrently in a pipelined manner, which requires a controlled coordination among shared system resources such as the main memory, CPU cores, system interconnect and IP cores. Towards this, in this exploratory 5-year project, we have attempted to optimize the energy-efficiency issue in several domains. First, to optimize the camera-memory flow for the camera pipeline, we have characterized the different types of value similarity in raw and encoded video buffers and exploited an iterative approximate base+delta compression algorithm to minimize the memory accesses. Second, to optimize the CPU-Microcontroller-Memory flow for IoT systems, we have explored runtime partitioning strategies by considering many parameters such as various communication options between the light-weight microcontroller based sensor hub and the relatively more energy consuming CPU cores, their runtime states and dynamic resource utilizations such as memory, battery power, etc. Third, to optimize the distributed edge-to-edge flow in DNN inference, we have proposed a distributed runtime framework that leverages the idle devices in an IoT system, to improve the throughput of an inference system by automatically partitioning and balancing the computation tasks across all available IoT devices. Last but not least, to optimize the network-SoC flow, we have modeled and integrated several network modules (e.g., WiFi, Bluetooth, LTE, 5G, etc.) into the GemDroid framework, and examined the energy and performance breakdown across several emerging IoT/mobile applications including VR/AR, gaming, virtual conference, video streaming, etc., to quantitatively identify the energy and performance bottlenecks. 

 

Not only the four research domains we have explored as discussed above, we believe energy-efficient flow-optimization is a critical area of research that would benefit the community in other ways. Based on our interaction with researchers in the hardware, compiler, algorithm and application areas, we expect that the flow based optimization will receive increasing attention in coming years.
